body.p:
Boone Furnace Ky. October 6" 1862
Gov. Robbinson
Dear Sir

We arrived at this place with seven Companys of the 117 Ohio V. Regt on the morning of the 5" about daylight, the Rebbels made an attack on this place on the eve^n^ing of the 4" inst before the men where at picket and at supper, firing in houses and and driving women & children to the woods taken all the goods in the Store Mules & Horsses away with them, value 3,000$.

This force is encampt at Olive Hill 11 to 1200 strong with 2 peices of arttilery they took two men from this place, one returned yesterday with this information the commanding officer by the name of Lt Col H A Edmonsun Tugg Regt Va the are the terror of the Union men here and have taken possession of the State Road from Cattletsburg. to Owingsville and plundering roabing the whole country of Horsses Mules & goods and subsistence, Men women & children are leaving the State for Ohio, men are afraid of staying as the press them in the Rebbel service

The Rebels have eaten out Morgan Pike and Countys South of the State Road from the Mouth of Sandy to Owingsville and are compelled to same north of that Road for supplies also keep up a line of communication with there forces in Kentucky and Va by that Road. and use it in case of a retreat for their forces to Va

This part of the State will have to have some protection please telegraph to the Gov of Ohio to let the 117. Regt O. V. take possession of that Road at Olive Hill them and a few companey of artilery Cavalry a a few peses of Artillery and we can raise 4 or 500 Home Guard can hold that Road and give protection to Carter Lewis Byrd & Greenup County, and the Ohio River or the Union Men will have to leave the State with there property and let the Rebels have full sway. The Home Guard killed 75 or 80 men of Morgans men in their late raid

Shall keep you posted in affairs here and should you want to telegraph send to Portsmouth Ohio. Telegraph to Gov Tod of Ohio ^or Gen H G. Wright^ for permission for this Regt to remain it will do more good here in Camp, as this is the point to protect the frontier of Ohio and River
better than have them stationed in Portsmouth

Please do all you can
Yours Respectfully
S. Eifort
